title: Paloma Faith is raising her child to be socially conscious
text:
Paloma Faith was honoured with the Empowerment Award at the Global Gift Gala (Picture: GC Images; Rex)

Paloma Faith admits it’s never been more important for people to have frank conversations about the climate emergency and humanitarian issues as she aims to raise her child to be socially conscious.

The singer, 38, revealed that her own upbringing instilled a sense of activism in her, and this is something she hopes will filter down into her own child.

She told Metro.co.uk at the Global Gift Gala on Thursday: ‘I think that will happen by nature because I was raised on quite a political trajectory and as a kid like we always went on marches and my mum was part of union, picket lines and all those sort of that kind of era.

‘And that’s very much ingrained in me. So I think that you don’t necessarily actively have to teach a child that you just lead by example.

‘Obviously I’ve got a three year old, I do explain those things. My child that knows why not to drop rubbish on the floor, and knows why we put different things in different bins and all that at age three.’

The Only Love Can Hurt Like This star shares her three-year-old child with partner Leyman Lahcine, and has decided not to reveal the child’s gender or name in public so they are able to live a normal life, rather than that of the child of a celebrity.

Paloma, who performed and was being honoured with the Empowerment Award on the night, is happy that people are now more outspoken about the issues in the world in order to effect change.

Paloma hung out with Melanie Griffith and Eva Longoria on the red carpet (Picture: Rex Features)

She explained: ‘It’s great to be part of a room full of very empowered, successful women who are doing their bit to contribute to a better world. God knows we need it right now.

‘I think the Zeitgeist at the moment is about being outspoken and being empowered about your views.

She also made her mark on a mural along with the other celeb attendees (Picture: GoffPhotos)

‘And I think that in the name of progress, no progress is going to be made unless we stand side by side and say we’re all human beings, what is the best thing to do for the greater good of the people and not the few?

Advertisement

‘Because actually, we are in a climate emergency and we’re in, you know, various other crises, humanitarian crises in the world. And actually, the issue really is that there’s a lack of conversation.

‘It’s not just about standing on your soapbox and saying, “Hey, this is what I think. And I’m empowered because I’m going to shout my opinions at you”.

‘It’s about actually saying “I need to understand why you oppose my view”. And to me, that’s true empowerment, not just somebody who’s swelling your ears with their opinion.’
